Basic Motions

Welcome to Programming Robots! This workshop is designed to introduce you to the basics of writing programs for robots. By the end of the workshop you will have programmed a robot to do cool things!

Starting Point


Always start with the mBot Program block.
Without this entry point, your program will not start.

Without the entry point, the mblock software will not know your program is an mBot program. Many different languages work this way too There must always be an entry point. What your mBlock program does is, it changes blocks you've placed in your editor and turns these blocks into C language code(see arduino mode)

Basic Motions


You can go forwards, backwards, turn right, turn left.
You can also alter your robot speed.

There are many other features you can add to your robot too, eg: LED lights, sensors, we will do more of this later. No angle option, get them thinking about how to make a perfect 90 degree angle. You can actually enter your own speed, every number you wish. With the speed you can choose from 0 - 255 or you can simply type whatever number you want.

Wait


The wait command means how long your previous block will go on for.
Try this program.

Wait does not meaning stopping and waiting, it simply means that your motion will go on for a certain amount of time.

Uploading Program to Robot

  • To see program code.
  • To upload program to mBot.
  • Your robot is ready to go!
Make sure your mBot is plugged in and connected through serial port before clicking on uploading.

Reset


Want to go again?
To repeat the program simply push the reset button on the robot.

This will make your program start from the beginning and repeat itself.

Angle

There is no precise way of turning your robot, every turn is measured in seconds.

How would you turn it exactly in quarter?

Ask students how they may figure out the angle from speed. The best way is to always keep the same speed, i would recommend 100, before any challenges get them to make the robot turn in speed 100 and use a stopwatch to time how long it takes for a full circle then divide by 4 The correct option should be 0.8 seconds for the wait command for a 90 degree angle. Make sure if you change speeds you will have to work out the angle again, as the speed affects the time taken to create an angle.

Challenge

Make your robot drive in a square
You should only need the basic motions we have covered.

Ok before we start, lets think about how we can make sure the robot is turning into a 90 degree angle. There is no angle option for the robot. Any suggestions on how you might work out the angle just from the speed? You will have to work out the how many seconds it takes turning at a speed of 100 until it completes a 360 degree angle then divide by 4.
